In other words, which shapes must only have counts made per edge segment instead of counting as pairs or triplets because any such shape would otherwise overcount certain distances multiple times during calculation?. Here’s another approach…$\qquad\qquad\quad f={ba\over cd},~g={\bar e\over da},\;h={{ef}\over ac},\;p={af\over d}\;;\;w={ec\over ab}$ So now..$\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\displaystyle s={dw\over cb}={db\over w}\,,r={eb\over wa}={wa\over eb};z=${ha}/${dc}\,{\;}q={ea}/${da}$,and thus:$~~~~~~~\Large{I = {\large{\!\[{df\over ba}\!-{\rm min}\Bigl\{ ({de\over ec}),

1.subquestion: In which row does every square appear at least once?

subanswer.text: By inspection, no single size appears more than twice in any row or column (because if they did, you could rearrange rows such that those would overlap.) Thus, since there are only seven nonzero entries per side and six different possible values; without loss of generality assume columns sorted smallest top down so that empty space must reside above smaller edges thus giving nine possibilities for edge placement resulting in eight remaining choices filling up remainder as needed yielding maximum case ${}\binom{9}{8}={9}$.

ost_step.1: If every square was large enough it adds one unit to both dimensions when placed horizontally ,when stacked vertically each takes exactly half the height away . Thereforestack themhorizontalyandyouwillhavea rectanglewithheight$(n+4)/2$width $n$,thathassquaresofonesizetofillthelargermosthorizontalrectangleexceptthe rightmostcolumnwhichcontainsone extra smallsquareonlytherewhereverothersquarecannotfit intotheir ${}(n+4)(n)=\text{ }70.$Solvingthisquadraticequationmodulointegerrootsprovidethesecondresultmakingoursecondsolution$\begin{array}{|l|} \hline {\bf {Answer:}~} & {-5~\text{

direct_answer.text: We know that the area of the larger rectangle formed by placing some squares horizontally would give us ${n+4}\cdot{n}=70$. Expanding this equation results in $n^2 + 4n - 70=0$. Factorizing this quadratic yields $(n+7)(n-10)=0$. As negative side lengths aren't possible here; therefore,$n=10$. Now let’s consider vertical placement as well. Stacking such squares vertically leaves behind gaps equal to twice the length of smaller track minus four ($2\cdot2-(2\cdot1)\cdot2$). However not more than eight tracks could fit into either top row or bottom row due to size restrictions—that leads us back again to our initial solution:$n=10$. Thus, using horizontal method makes sense because while considering other methods like rotation may seem appealing but eventually brings no change whether width decreases or increases based on position i.e., doesn’t affect overall count hence better option left over.

subanswer.text: From the provided information, let's consider the following cases for placing the big black blocks:

direct_answer.text: First, note that each block occupies four unit cells in the same horizontal line when placed vertically. To get exactly one layer filled completely horizontally using whole blocks implies that \(70 / 4 = 17\) full layers plus part of an extra cell left over because \(70 \) isn’t divisible cleanly by \(4\). Hence it’s clear how much floor area covers even parts ––namely zero! But what happens next?? Here comes **Expectancy Maximisation** again ! Now suppose I had used twenty little pebbles instead ….. ****what* ***would happen now ?? Well…well , well !! Because expectations change .....hence outcomes too.....so logic tells us ----------> If ten tiny stones go into place XYZ region already occupied by MNO items ........then obviously :****Only ONE TINY PIECE WOULD FIT HERE BECAUSE THOSE NINE OTHERS UNDER ROOT REQUIRE SPACE TO MOVE UP AND SAVES OUT OF THE ROW IN WHICH EACH COVERS FOUR UNIT CELLS!!! subanswer.text: In geometry, when calculating areas using coordinate methods like Pick's theorem, it's important to consider how lines intersect each other. Specifically, you want to avoid double-counting intersections. Trapezoids fit your criteria perfectly under those circumstances – particularly regular ones without holes inside —because unlike polygons sharing sides (like parallelograms &c.) ,trapeziums don’t get split into smaller parts through shared diagonals along crosses.. Instead what happens every time one side gets crossed out again later becomes just another straight path linking up somewhere else! 1.subquestion: In which row does every square appear at least once?

subanswer.text:
To determine which row contains each type of shape appearing at least once, let us consider both rows separately starting from leftmost column as follows:

**Row 1** - Triangle: Square appears twice; Rectangle: Appears four times; Pentagon: Does not exist.
In Row 1, triangles always come first followed by rectangles since no other shapes occupy positions before them according to our order constraint.
